Shame on you. I was 4 miles away at another facility on the same day. No one is being dishonest. These border facilities are a national disgrace, with human beings kept in conditions worse than prisons, children sleeping on floors. These facilities have become edifices to hate. https://twitter.com/VP/status/1149879269373300736 …
We need to get these law-abiding children and families out of these facilities. We need an immigration system that doesn’t promote cruelty and degradation in the name of the American people.

The orders CBP and ICE are receiving from the Trump administration offer little but pain and humiliation for children and families. These are human beings. President Trump is treating them worse than criminals and turning them into pawns in his craven political games.

The Trump administration is intentionally making conditions at the border so horrendous in hopes that migrants will look at these facilities and determine that risking violence or death in their home countries is the better option.

CBP staff confirmed stories we heard of women making the trip begging for birth control, condoms, and morning-after pills for themselves + their daughters because they know they may be raped at some point during the journey or while waiting at the border.

There are no clean clothes in these facilities. There are no toothbrushes or toothpaste. There are no showers. This is the facility where sick people are sent and they have little access to proper hygiene as they try to recover.
The lights are on 24 hours a day, so families often wrap themselves in layers of the Mylar blankets to block out the light so they can sleep.

There are no beds in the cells. Migrants, including young children, sleep on the floor or on concrete slabs. CBP says they lean against one another to get comfortable. They are given only Mylar blankets.

The Weslaco Border Patrol Station is 5 miles from the U.S.-Mexico border. It is known as the “infirmary” because migrants in the Rio Grande Valley Sector are sent there when they have contagious diseases – flu, chicken pox, impetigo, etc.
I visited two Customs and Border Patrol facilities on the southern border and what I witnessed was shameful. THREAD:

From late July to late November 2018, ICE arrested 170 potential sponsors of UACs, 64% of whom had no criminal record. ICE is also targeting asylum seekers, immigrant victims of crime, and children who have recently aged out of the foster care system.
Trump’s ICE is intentionally targeting vulnerable populations and those who support them. Over the past 2 years, ICE has targeted sponsors of UACs.
Trump’s Department of Justice has reinterpreted the definition of UACs to strip protections from children previously determined to be UACs.

Unaccompanied alien children (UACs) are children under age 18 who have no lawful immigration status and who have no parent or legal guardian in the United States, or have no parent or legal guardian in the United States available to provide care and physical custody.
But Trump’s Attorneys General have used this to restrict discretion of immigration judges, advance partisan political objectives, and unilaterally reinterpret immigration law.

The Attorney General can overturn immigration court decisions by “self-referring” them. Previous AGs have wielded this power cautiously because these decisions can affect hundreds of thousands of immigrants.
The Trump admin is now revisiting thousands of cases the Obama admin administratively closed and ICE is considering revisiting all 355,000 administratively closed cases.

“Administrative closure” removes a case from an active court docket and halts deportation proceedings. Often used to provide relief to, for example, parents of U.S. citizen children or immigrants who have lived here for decades without a criminal record.
Over the past two years, the State Department has ordered reductions in the number of refugee resettlement offices ­- citing the self-inflicted problem of few refugee arrivals.

For fiscal year 2018, Trump set refugee admissions at a record-low 45,000 (historical average is 95,000). The next year he slashed admissions to a mere 30,000. His administration is now using this manufactured slowdown to dismantle our resettlement program.

I’m voting NO.

Amazon is not doing enough to ensure that its products and practices do not run afoul of our civil liberties.

Ring has:

-no security requirements for law enforcement that gets access to users’ footage

-no restrictions on law enforcement sharing users’ footage with third parties

-no policies that prohibit law enforcement from keeping shared video footage forever

This is nothing short of chilling. Amazon Ring’s policies are an open door for privacy and civil liberty violations. With the Turkey Human Rights Promotion Act, we can send a message to the people of Turkey: we will not rest until you have the rights to which you are entitled.

The Turkish government also heavily restricts and censors the internet, blocking more than 220,000 websites including Wikipedia – and temporarily including Twitter and YouTube. It is now pressuring Netflix and other online streaming platforms to censor content.

By the end of 2018, the Government of Turkey had:

-Arrested or imprisoned more than 80,000 Turkish citizens 

-Closed more than 1,500 nongovernmental organizations on terrorism-related grounds

-Dismissed or suspended more than 130,000 civil servants from their jobs
Erdogan has forcibly closed at least 180 media outlets in the past three years, and was detaining at least 68 journalists and media workers at the end of 2018.

For the first time since 1980, Canada resettled more refugees than the U.S. With more than 24 million refugees around the globe and 70 million displaced persons, America must step into our leadership role, not away from it. https://www.cnn.com/2019/06/19/americas/canada-us-refugee-resettlement-hnk-intl/index.html …

More often than not, we have answered that call — and today, it sounds to us louder than ever. But after centuries of opening our door to the persecuted, the Trump administration has forsaken our historic commitment to the world’s most vulnerable.

The first settlers fleeing religious oppression. Irish Catholics fleeing starvation. Eastern European Jews fleeing the pogroms. Syrians fleeing civil war. At nearly every juncture since its founding, America has been called upon to be a leader in welcoming the persecuted.

On #WorldRefugeeDay, we keep in our hearts the millions of refugees around the globe who, despite facing devastating circumstances, display remarkable strength every day as they seek refuge for themselves and their loved ones.

As oceans warm, our iconic fisheries are suffering as lobster and cod move north, out of Massachusetts waters. Ocean acidification threatens our shellfish industry and coastal ecosystems. We need healthy oceans, but our oceans need us too. They need #OceanClimateAction.

Sea level rise is accelerating. 90,000 homes in Massachusetts could face inundation from sea level rise by 2100, according to @UCSUSA. Warming waters will fuel more extreme storms and flooding, with disadvantaged and underserved communities most at risk.

Off Massachusetts’s coasts, the Gulf of Maine is the fastest-warming body of water behind the Arctic. Our waters are already experiencing over 2°C of warming—past the Paris goal for avoiding climate catastrophe. Climate change is here and now. https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2019/national/climate-environment/climate-change-world/ …

The ocean has absorbed 90% of the heat from our CO2 emissions, but we’re straining its capacity to shield us from climate impacts. The IPCC SROCC report warns of critical tipping points in melting ice, warming waters, rising seas—all threats to coastal communities & economies

The #IPCC #SROCC report is clear: we need #OceanClimateAction. To protect our oceans & coastal communities, we need a transition to 100% clean, renewable energy. TSA needs ample resources to complete its critical mission. That’s why @SenBlumenthal and I have introduced legislation to ensure that 100% of the September 11th Security Fee goes towards aviation security.

After 9/11, Congress established a fee tacked onto airline tickets to help finance the mission of securing our nation’s transportation system. But in 2013, Congress started to divert 1/3 of this revenue for “deficit reduction.” We need to stop raiding these funds.
This year, I was proud to vote to finally make sure the 9/11 victims’ fund never runs out of money. Our gratitude for these heroic first responders will last forever, and now, so will our commitment.

Today, we remember those who lost their lives on September 11, 2001. That day was one of incredible horror but also one of incredible courage by first responders and ordinary Americans who risked everything in the face of unspeakable tragedy. We owe it to them to #NeverForget.

Where the FTC fails, Congress must act. We can start by passing my COPPA 2.0 legislation w/ @SenHawleyPress that extends privacy protections to teens, creates an eraser button so that young users can eliminate personal info they’ve posted, and bans targeted ads directed at kids.
The FTC should have required annual public audits into Google’s children’s privacy practices because parents deserve to know if this tech behemoth continues to track kids.

The FTC should have prohibited Google from launching any new kids’ offerings before review and approval by independent experts because Google has forfeited the benefit of the doubt when it comes to putting kids’ well-being first.
The FTC should have required Google to delete all data it has collected from children under 13 because it never should have amassed an untold amount of this data in the first place.
The FTC should have issued a colossal fine that fits Google’s crime and demanded that Google make significant structural changes to their business practices.

YouTube knowingly broke federal law by tracking kids in order to rake in advertising dollars without the requisite notice to and permission from parents. But the FTC let Google off the hook with a drop-in-the-bucket fine. Not a single Google executive or investor will bat an eye. https://twitter.com/nytimes/status/1169237574709403648 …
